item.title: Windows 8
item.dc:creator: @Unlimited1 .Unlimited
item.description:
@Unlimited1 wrote:

According to http://www.engadget.com/2011/06/01/microsoft-unveils-windows-8-tablet-prototypes/

There will be 2 different environments the Tablet/Touchscreen one and a traditional desktop version.

There'll be two kinds of applications for Windows 8, one that runs in a traditional desktop, and the other pseudo-mobile apps based on HTML5 and Javascript, but both environments -- rather, the entire OS -- have been designed from the ground up for touchscreen use. Keyboard and mouse will still be options for both sets of programs, but there are multiple virtual sets of keys for different form factors, including a split keyboard for vertical slate use. Multitasking is simply a matter of swiping running apps into the center of the screen, and you can pull windows partway to "snap" them in place alongside other windows -- even mixing and matching traditional desktop programs with web apps simultaneously (like Twitter alongside your spreadsheet). There's a new version of Internet Explorer 10 (which runs Silverlight) and an app store built into the touchscreen interface, along with integrated services like Office 365. Microsoft says the new OS will run on laptops, tablets and desktops when it appears -- whenever that might be.

item.title: Windows 8
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:4, topic:397693”]right i love the UI, its beautiful. However there are a substantial amount of issues that i notice in that video:
Firstly that sort of UI whilst looking good is very much designed more for the tablet space where people can touch with their finger and scroll through. My opinion of this is that this is a bad move, you dont want to be alienating the main user base, which will be those with mouse and keyboards, with your UI. It could be used effectively i think if it was scrollable with the mouse wheel, but then it would make more sense to be vertical. Clicking and dragging to go through the tiles would be a chore and not something i would be comfortable doing.Secondly when they load up the application for excel we can still see the taskbar, from my point of view this conflits with the initial design choice, that should not be there likewise there should be no desktop, there should just be this tiles thing as a core part of the OS when you open it up and that becomes your new desktop they can’t have features from both of these ways of working imo it’ll lead to the OS just not looking or feeling right. The tiles thing should not be running like an application which is what it appears, Microsoft have work to do on this imo[/quote]
pretty sure this interface was only made for touch screen devices… old interface will still be available im sure
